The "Ban the Box Act" prohibits unlawful employment practices related to the criminal record of applicants. The "Ban the Box Act" prohibits employers from inquiring about an applicant's criminal record before a conditional job offer is made, except in cases where the job may pose a risk to safety. SEC. 3. RULEMAKING.

Within 1 year of this Act's enactment, the Commission will establish rules defining employment categories where an individual's criminal history may pose a risk and factors for employers to consider.

SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The powers, procedures, and remedies under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 apply to unlawful employment practices against covered employees, with exceptions regarding costs and fees. The powers, remedies, and procedures provided under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 apply to unlawful employment practices, with exceptions regarding costs and fees. The Revised Statutes of the United States (42 U.S.C. 1988) outline the powers, remedies, and procedures for the Commission, Attorney General, or any person alleging such practices, including damages specified in section 1977A (42 U.S.C. 1981a). The powers, remedies, and procedures provided in the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 apply to violations of unlawful employment practices, with exceptions regarding costs and fees outlined in the Revised Statutes of the United States. The powers, remedies, and procedures under the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 apply to claims of unlawful employment practices, with exceptions outlined in the Revised Statutes of the United States. The powers, remedies, and procedures under the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 apply to claims of unlawful employment practices, with exceptions outlined in the Revised Statutes of the United States. Specifically, Chapter 5 of Title 3, United States Code, provides powers, remedies, and procedures for addressing violations of section 411(a)(1) against certain employees. The powers, remedies, and procedures provided in the Revised Statutes of the United States apply to claims of unlawful employment practices, including damages and limitations. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 covers employees in this regard. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 provides powers, remedies, and procedures for employees alleging unlawful employment practices. These provisions apply to employees covered under this Act, with exceptions outlined in the text. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 provides powers, remedies, and procedures for employees alleging unlawful employment practices, including damages and coverage under specific sections of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 provides powers, remedies, and procedures for employees alleging unlawful employment practices under the Civil Rights Act of 1964. These include costs and fees outlined in specific sections of the Act. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 provides powers, remedies, and procedures for employees alleging unlawful employment practices. Damages and limitations are outlined in section 1977A of the Act for individuals or entities making such claims. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The curr_chunk defines terms such as "Commission" as the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and "employer" as per the Civil Rights Act of 1964, including specific entities like employing offices and State employees. The term "employee" includes individuals covered by various acts such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995. The term "person" in the context of employment law refers to individuals covered by the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Act will be effective one year after its enactment.
